article.headline: GrubHub posts Q2 loss on COVID-19 costs, but expresses optimism
article.body: GrubHub Inc. GRUB, +0.83%, the online food-ordering company, posted a greater loss than expected in the second quarter, citing costs of helping its restaurant partners during the COVID-19 pandemic. "To be clear, we made a deliberate choice to spend approximately $100 million in largely one-time, discretionary costs during the quarter to support local restaurants and our operations," said Matt Maloney and Adam DeWitt, CEO and CFO of the company, in a letter to shareholders. Shares are down about 1.5% to $69.89 in midday trading Thursday. The Chicago-based company, which is being acquired by Just Eat Takeaway and did not hold an earnings call, reported a loss of $45.4 million, or 49 cents a share, versus net income of $1.3 million, or 1 cent a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings were 23 cents a share, adjusted for the aforementioned restaurant and driver support. Revenue rose to $459 million from $325 million in the year-ago quarter. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast a loss of 17 cents a share on revenue of $459 million. GrubHub did not issue guidance, but in their letter to shareholders, the company's top executives talked about a strong third quarter so far. "We now believe the pandemic has been less of a temporary demand spike and more of a permanent catalyst putting our business on a higher, sustained trajectory," Maloney and DeWitt wrote. GrubHub shares are up nearly 49% this year, while the S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% is up 1.9% so far.
